Yes, this place is a chain. But I worked at the mall for about a year and a half, and if I wanted to get food after work at someplace a bit nicer than the food court or Chipotle, this was one of the better options. I would not recommend it for PIZZA pizza (tomato sauce, cheese, pepperoni, GREASE) but they do have a lot of interesting specialty pizzas. The menu is quite large and diverse. It does kind of have that overall blandness that I've come to associate with chain restaurants -- while everything I've tried is good, nothing was particularly exciting or unexpected. Actually, that's not true -- they have pizzas with salad ON THEM. That's pretty unusual, unless it's a California thing; I wouldn't know. I haven't tried one because they just sound weird. The personal pizza is usually a bit too big for me to eat in one sitting, but leftovers are nice. It's worth getting a box for your leftovers instead of stuffing yourself here, because they have good desserts. Key Lime Piiiieeeee.... The drinks are also good. I love love love their dessert coffee drink Almond Joy, which includes amaretto, coconut rum and chocolate syrup. Yummmm. Here's the thing that always bothers me about this place, though. They have a very strange service policy, that apparently is enforced by corporate, that I don't like. Servers all introduce themselves in their flat, scripted way ("Hi! I'm John and I'll be serving you tonight! Can I tell you about our specials?") and every time I've eaten there, the manager on duty has come around at least once during the meal and asked us how we are doing. This might seem like a nice touch, but it feels very corporate-enforced. I've had two separate managers do this, a man and a woman, and both of them seemed almost suspicious of their servers. "Is everything okay? Reeeally?" It was a weird attitude to have, because we were doing just fine, and it made me feel like there was something weird going on except that this seems to happen every time (I've asked some co-workers if they had that happen too, and they all did.) So, Corporate, if you're reading this, STOP MAKING THEM DO IT! It's really annoying and weird. The food and drinks are quite good, but the most this place will get is four stars (really 3.5) because of the weird service issues.

There are occasions when things get busy and it might take them a bit longer to get back to you but they are normally on point and they aren't bothersome.  I've had the entire variety of spring rolls which are my faves as far as appetizers go, my husband normally get's the Chipotle pizza whereas I'm more diverse. I have sampled numerous items on the menu and have yet to be disappointed. The salads are delish and large in portions...event the half salads are decent sizes and filling. The Chinese chicken salad is so good! They also have a new entree featuring the cedar plank salmon with corn succotash and I thought it was to die for. Personally it had the right amount of spice, it was cooked perfectly, and the fish was just delicious. I couldn't stop talking about it after I left. $18 for that dish and I thought it was worth it.  I also like the fact that they have a separate booklet that helps you compare nutrition facts and calories for those who are dieting. Because I don't get the pizza, I can say I haven't had any issues with greasiness or oily foods. Everything seems so fresh and tastes good. For such a large menu I commend that cooking brigade for getting all those dishes out. Keep up the good work and keep it clean!!!

Even though it's great to know that this place has updated its menu, I was bummed that they didn't have the Thai chicken pasta anymore. So I opted for an Italian chopped salad instead. There wasn't enough dressing, not enough meat, and the "large" portion still wasn't that big.  However, we did see the mayor of Seattle here which was pretty cool. My friend didn't believe that it was him until I showed her a Youtube video of him...and then she believed me.  Anyway, this place is just meh. I'm sure the pizza is still decent...I'd go for that the next time I need some high school flashbacks.

I find it a little awkward when I go to California Pizza Kitchen when I'm not in California anymore. I never gave it a second thought but now when I read the menu, I imagine a blonde surfer dude advertising the healthy and fresh California-style of food you came to this restaurant for! My favorites at this restaurant remain the thai crunch salad, which I resorted to after they took away the miso seafood salad. I still mourn the loss of that salad. I'm adventurous with pizzas, but I like the pear and gorgonzola or the thai chicken. I'm pretty sure there used to be a peking duck that was great but not on the menu anymore. That's another thing I'm disappointed about of CPK. I've been going here since my childhood because it's one of the few non-asian restaurants my chinese food eating mom liked. I've seen their menu change a lot in recent years and much of what I grew to love is gone. It's sad. I have a feeling their consolidating their menu to get rid of ingredients that were only used in certain entrees and thus weren't price effective to keep in the kitchen. Having crab just for one salad or duck just for one pizza probably isn't smart.  CPK isn't a very expensive restaurant, and their pizzas seem to have gotten bigger even though the price hasn't changed much. I'll still come here because I'm used to it and familiar restaurant decor makes me happy, but I'll always remember that I used to like it better.

I had been to CPK years ago before I knew my allergy was a gluten allergy. When I found out I couldn't eat anything delicious anymore, I was bummed. I was also bummed that CPK wasn't jumping onto the GF bandwagon like most places.  Until recently. And they really did their homework. They are certified GF and take every precaution. It's wonderful. They have also perfected their pizza crust recipe so that they have a thin, crispy crust that you can't even tell is Gluten Free! They cook the pizza in a separate place with a separate person and a manager delivers it to your table. No cross contamination. And it tastes great! My favorite is the BBQ Chicken.  They don't have any other GF entrees, but some of the salads and things are safe. I'm so glad I have a reason to come back to CPK! If you're severely allergic, like I am, then you can safely eat here.

I haven't been to a CPK in years, but I had time to kill to avoid traffic. I was not feeling great, so I just wanted something reliable.  Good: The mushroom pizza was very good when adding the truffle oil. If I ordered it again, I would add arugula.  The managers buzzing around were very friendly and on top of things. Surprisingly good beer selection, but you have to ask about what's on tap.  Most of the staff I encountered was very friendly.  Free wifi is always a bonus.  Meh:  The uniforms are so dated. The headsets that all servers and managers wear are really cheesy, bordering on annoying. No, not bordering on - they are really annoying. No real reason why, jmho.  Bad: My server said I had poor taste because I like mushrooms and truffles. I get it was joking around, but inappropriate.  The interior of the restaurant is incredibly dated, to the point of being uncomfortable. It felt like a Denny's with all the low booths and bad design. I'm not an interior decorator, so I can't put my finger on it, other than do say it could use refreshing.  The truffle oil is very expensive and tasted like a 'fake' truffle oil. It was so strong that I assume it was enhanced with synthetic scent/flavor.  With 5 tables or so in the entire place, I fell victim to mediocre distracted service. Two basic requests were forgotten (water and condiments).  Only the manager knew what was in a basic bar drink that was ordered. The first thing a bartender should learn are things like a Collins, a press, a sour, a spritzer... No happy hour.  I'm not one that frequents chains like this, but didn't know the area and needed something reliable and easy to navigate.  I remember visiting early CPKs years and years ago when they first opened in SoCal, and I was happy to see that the pizza quality was still as good as remembered, again, understanding what it is. But, because of the interior and flip server, I do not plan on returning the next time I have time to kill in that area.

It took a while for our waiter to make his way over to us, but he made up for the initial delay with friendly service and attention throughout our meal. So, what can I say... if you've been to CPK, then you know their food is solid. The kids enjoyed their fusilli with cream sauce, barbeque chicken pizza and pepperoni pizza (picky eater child, of course). I convinced my husband to share the chopped barbeque chicken salad and Margherita pizza - seriously, I love that thin and chewy crust! I was lucky he obliged, since he sacrificed his usual Kung Pao spaghetti to share my favorites with me.

I come in regularly - sometimes alone, sometimes w/ my husband.  I love the staff - they are very good (waitpeople) and the food is pretty good.  Normally, I'd leave 5 stars for those two reasons, but today, they get bumped down to 2.  My waitress, Madison, was wonderful - attentive and friendly and fast.  However, I came in early - 11:15am and only two other people were there at the counter.  The music was very loud - I think they turn it up when they are setting up the restaurant.  This is superbowl Sunday - the game is set to begin at 3pm and the TV's were on, but weren't playing through the speakers.  I asked Madison to turn down the music just a little bit and she consented.  About 3 minutes later, the sound switched to the TV and got incredibly loud.  So loud that the words distorted.  I looked up and over at the food prep area (which is open for everyone to see) and the entire cook staff and manager, Carl, were staring at me.  It was very odd and seemed to be a FU to me.  I can't understand why - they know me there and I am always very polite and tip well so there was no reason for hostility.  And, it wasn't an accident since they were just staring at me.  The TV was broadcasting some inane interview with foreign reporters about what they thought about the upcoming game - so it wasn't even that interesting or relevant.  After about 2 minutes, Carl turned down the TV to the original, still-too-loud volume, and I guess the message was that I should be thankful for that volume because of what it could have been.  I doubt he would have done that if there were other customers besides me at a booth eating and two guys at the counter drinking.  The waitress came back and apologized and said that the manager really wanted to hear the game.  What game?  There was no game playing and we were 4 hours before it.  About 15 minutes later, a couple was seated at the booth behind me.  Madison waited on them too and they could not hear her.  She kept raising her voice and still the man couldn't understand what she was telling him about this menu options.  It was ridiculous.  Maybe Carl was in a bad mood because he had to work today - whatever his reason, his behavior was very unprofessional and immature and everyone that works there recognized that.

The service and food I recieved was phenomenal; worth four stars, but when I was sitting at the bar on a busy Friday afternoon, I had a chance to observe how they run the kitchen and their staff.....not five stars.  There were probably 30 or so guests sitting in the dining area and only two servers and a manager-looking type woman....who didn't do much of anything even though she was frantically running around.  My Food: Starter- the guacamole  ($3.99) The portion was small for the hoard of chips that accompanied it. But it was very tasty. Up the portion and I would eat it for lunch everyday. Entree: half of the Asian Chicken Salad ($9.99) very good, I loved the crunch it had and the peanut sauce. Maybe a bit on the salty side, but I ate it all; I was hungry.  Monica was my server, but she was in a rush to assist her dining room guests so I was mostly assisted by the manager on duty.  Every time Monica asked the manager for help with an easy task, the manager would either attempt it and fail, or ignore her request all together. Even the hostess was able to dart to the kitchen and run some food!!!!!  At one point, the manager was ringing a to go order with the guest standing right there, and had some issue with the cash register! Wouldn't you know it, even though she was slammed, Monica stepped in and finished the transaction.  I also noticed that the hot pizzas were sitting out, waiting to be delivered for too long. No one was to blame as the two servers were trying to tackle the near impossible.  It's employees like Monica that really keep a restaurant in businesss. If her pace had slowed in the least, it would have resulted in angry customers and cold food. Even though she didn't order or deliver my food (the manager did), she was still very kind and checked in with me enough for me to tip her handsomely and give her an honest compliment on her work ethic.  Contrastingly, it's people like this manager that can drag a business down. More servers should be hired on the weekend so the employees don't experience burnout and the guests are happily fulfilled. Also, the manager should know how to do almost every task to better support the employees....just in case it gets busy (like today). Running food, taking orders, making drinks and correctly ringing to-go orders.  They really have great food, but the management side of things needs to shape up.

I already filed a complaint through their national office, so this will be brief and to the point: Restaurant closes at 10p, I asked if they were still serving at 9:50p and was seated. Party of 2. - 9:51p Waitress #1 immediately appears announcing the kitchen was closing and we needed to order, I order drinks but ask for at least a minute to decide - 9:53p Waiter #2 delivers wrong drink order, but takes entre order, promising to get correct drunk order. We order 2 full pizzas and a salad. They never did correct the drink order. - No bread brought to the table (forgot about this until their national Web page asked if the free bread was brought as it should be). - 10:05p waitress #1 brings salad and pizzas together, announcing that restaurant is closing.  I get it:  everyone wants to go home.  you don't really want us here... despite the fact you seated us. But salads are traditionally appetizers and brought before the meal. thanks for trying to speed us along by bringing it all at once, but... never mind. Sent back the salad since it wasn't brought first. - 10:10p busboy begins bussing table next to us, bringing his fully loaded tray of used dishes while the couple next to us WERE STILL EATING. I get ready to yell at busboy if he should do the same to me. Busboy appears to notice the look on my face and goes back inside. - 10:12p Waitress #1, to her credit does ask if the *food* is okay. - No further checks on us; waitress #1 and Waiter #2 ignore us, despite cashing out couple sitting next to us. I have to call waitress #1 as she walks past us to ask her for refills on our empty glasses. - Waitress #1 lets me know they have "dumped all the lemonade because they're closed" (!?) so no refills are available. I asked for the general manager... who appeared offended that I bothered him and was complaining.  His only response was that they close at 10 and, the restaurant was now closed. Oh... but he took the $2 lemonade off the bill. We packed up the food and left by 10:20p.  Sorry I kept them late. Not going back. I spend my $$$ at restaurants who appear happy that I'm there and interested in giving me a place to relax.

It's hard for me to decide how many stars to give. My most recent visit went from hugely disappointing to remarkable in the span of 10 minutes. Let me explain. I get the Thai chicken pizza nearly every time, and nearly every time it's great. Except once. After placing my order and waxing effusive to my friend about how incredible the Thai chicken pizzas are, the waiter dropped off a dry, sad looking, flat, flimsy pie absent of adequate sauce or toppings. My reaction was mildly visceral. I took one bite. To be fair, it tasted marginally better than it looked. But it was not nearly as good as I remembered. A 3 out of 10 at best. Now I hardly ever send food back. Let's just say I'm paranoid about disgruntled kitchen crews adding foreign "toppings" to my order. But today, a CPK District Manager happened to be making the rounds, asking how everyone's food was. When she approached our table, I told her my dish was "OK, but it used to be really good in the past." She apologized and said: "Let me take care of that for you," and whisked the sorry thing away. About 10 minutes later she returned, apologizing again for the wait. And what she placed in front of me was nothing short of legendary. The crust was perfect. The sauce was perfect. The toppings were piled comically high. It looked almost too good to eat. But I ate it. And it was the one of the best pizzas I've ever had.  Now she didn't say so, but I think the DM made my pizza that day. But whoever made it got it right. I only wish every CPK zaw was that amazing.

My bf and I came here for lunch today. I ordered the Chicken Tequila Fettuccine while he had the Chicken Club with baked potato soup. We shared a sangria flight special they had.  There were a few things wrong with our visit. Where to start... We wanted to sit outside and asked if they would turn on the outdoor heater. It was a little brisk out but still a beautiful day. One waiter said sure but they only turn them on in the evenings so she'd have to get someone to turn it on. Once we were seated, another waiter said they aren't working so great right now, so they won't turn it on. Okay... I waited 15 minutes for the bread basket, and when I realized after 3 times the waitress stopped by that it wasn't coming, I asked if they still offer it. She said yes and brought it out a few minutes later. My pasta dish was ok, not great but not bad. I'd give that 3 stars.  The sangria flight was interesting to try, although nothing I would order again. His soup was ok, a little salty and bland though. The sandwich was good, but about 3 bites in he felt a sharp piece of plastic in it. We let the waiter know and she had the sandwich remade, but not to our specifications to accommodate food allergies.  When we asked for the check, she happily told us she didn't charge us for the second sandwich/soup combo - the one we had to send back because they made it wrong. But she still charged us for the first one - the one that we sent back because it had bits of plastic in it. Why would we pay for either of them?? We asked her to please remove the charge for the sandwich, not the soup which he ate, and explained why. She did that, but we're baffled as to why we had to ask. I would give 2 stars for quality of food. And one star for customer service.

Wow!  What a strange and horrible experience! I've been a long-time CPK fan -- particularly when traveling for business, when you want to go somewhere that is going to have quickly served at least pretty good food that isn't going to get you a call from the accountant after you submit your expense report.  CPK has been that place for me (kudos to the Oak Brook, Illinois location, where I've spent many a dinner after a day at a local client site). So, I know what to expect, as do my wife and kids.  But, noooooo.  Not this time.  While the food was most definitely sub-par (the mac and cheese, which is usually good, was flavorless and the salmon salad was pretty much inedible), we going to talk about something else today.  What might that be?  Why, our waiter, of course. In short, I'm really not even sure how to explain what went wrong.  I actually found myself mentally trying to put the story together prior to asking for the manager to come by, and I found that nothing I could say would really do justice to the situation. He took our drink order.  No drinks appeared.  After quite a while, we nicely asked for our drinks.  He asked what we ordered.  Told him again.  No drinks.  But he spent an inordinate amount of time at the terminal, flipping through his pad and punching things into the computer. He brings bread to the table, which is immediately consumed by hungry family. Still no drinks. Finally came by to take our food order.  That took a while. Goes directly to another table to take their order, rather than punching our order into the computer.  He's there for a loooong time. One drink appears! We ask for the rest of the drinks.  He asks what we ordered. We ask for more bread. YAY!  The kids' meals appear!  Nope.  They're kids meals, but not for our kids.  He takes them away and sort of starts offering them to the occupants of his various tables.  They appeared to eventually find a home in front of some children a few tables away. Still no food.  And one drink.  We ask for drinks again.  Waiter asks what kind of tea my wife had ordered, which we took as a good sign that he at least remembered she ordered tea. Drinks appear! We see waiter sort of aimless walking around with a plate of bread.  Eventually he diverts to our table.  Yes!  Bread!  Three pieces for four people. Waited a while longer, and the food appears.  See above note about quality of the food). I think we must have had "a look" on our faces, because one of the other waitstaff was walking by and stopped.  She wanted to know if everything was OK.  No, she wasn't the manager.  I could only incoherently mumble something about "bad" due to no clear manner of explaining the dystopian dining situation in which we'd found ourselves. We ate what we could that was sort of edible.  Shared our plates to ensure that nobody left too hungry -- you know, like a pack of leopards around a fallen gazelle.  Somebody else was clearing our table, when our waiter appears. . . with a caesar salad.  No, we didn't order it.  He looks confused.  Or crestfallen.  Or crestfused.  Whatever.  We had't ordered it. He finally asks if we want refills on our drinks. The manager comped the entire meal.  We didn't even have to ask her to do so or ask her to come to the table.  At some point she just figured out what was going on.  Sort of like when you pass an accident and see everybody standing by their cars on the side of the highway.  I think that's pretty much what she saw going on at our table. We're probably not going to be back for a while.

This restaurant serves very hearty and rich foods. Every bite is dripping with some butter or cheese. Basically, not a place to go if one is being mindful of some sort of body transforming New Year's resolution. However, with that being said, this review is for a "Rich and Hearty Pizza" restaurant. I had ordered the Rib Eye steak and the jambalaya. This place is not a great place to get a good steak, but they'll charge steak house rates. (Price of the steak was $27.99) The meat was tough and lacked flavor. I ordered the steak done medium well and there was "rare" blood pooling on the curls of the steak. I suppose the brick of cheese set on top of the steak was intended to mask the low quality of the cut, but it really didn't help. I was basically eating cheesy rib eye steak. Now onto the Jambalaya, the dish wasn't too bad. Every bite was an explosion of flavor down down to the last bit. Some may enjoy this sort of flavoring, but I just felt it was over powering the good ingredients. The Jambalaya had shrimp, crawfish, sausage, and a tasty pasta. I couldn't finish the dish, but the first few bites were very delicious. I don't want to knock this restaurant due to it not appealing to my palette, but just know that this place serves very rich and hearty foods.

California Pizza Kitchen has no business charging premium prices for their food. This is a Cheesecake Factory style Highschool Prom night date restaurant. That being said, I digress... After the friendly hostess seated us. I noticed the restaurant was maybe one third full of customers and they had 3-4 servers so I figured we'd get decent service. I was wrong. For some reason, the server we had seemed relatively attentive and friendly when she first came to take our drink order but then everything went downhill from there. For some reason my drink (and water) took a bit of time to arrive, but that wasn't really a big deal and the server even apologized for the wait. The first problem was when I asked for red paper flakes with my pizza and I never got it. By the time the server arrived to check on us(something she did maybe 1-2 times during our meal and was mostly ignoring us) I was almost done with my pizza and since we were trying to catch a movie I just put down my credit card and didn't mention the missing red pepper flakes. We did ask for a box for my wife's very undercooked and overpriced gluten free pizza; figuring we'd cook it more later at home. We thought about sending her pizza back, but we didn't want to miss our movie.  Well, we never got the box and on top of that the server had charged me for someone else's pizza and I had to flag down the friendly and helpful hostess to get our box and get our bill fixed. After our bill was mostly fixed we received a very halfhearted apology from our server and $50 later; we left.  Yeah that's right. 2 very small gluten free pizzas, no appetizers, a coke ($3.50) and a moscow mule(10 bucks) All of this was more than 50 dollars... Seattle isn't known for their pizza, but there are plenty of places that offer cheaper and higher quality gluten free pizza and have better service. On top of all that my stomach felt not so great afterward.  Save your money.

As a long-time lover of CPK, I can't explain my extreme disappointment with this location. My friend, Rach and I wanted salads and wine before a little shopping and I insisted on my favorite salad spot, CPK. We walked in and no one was at the host stand, so we waited. And waited. And waited. And waited. Finally, we decided to sit at the bar top. We were greeted by the enthusiastic and hospitable, Richard. He greeted us with menus and a smile then hurried over to run food. Clearly understaffed, we watched 2 servers (and 2 trainees..) Sprint around the restaurant, trying to give sufficient service.  We ordered drinks and salads and Richard was friendly and attentive, but clearly brief due to being stretched to thin. Our drinks came out perfect and we enjoyed them thoroughly. The girl with the two trainees was near, so we asked her for water and she said she would deliver them soon. She then within earshot said 'sometimes guests who aren't yours will bug you for things and you have deal with it'. Not exactly a comment appreciated by the ones who asked it. The AGM with a branded coat hardly noticed any of the customer service faux paus occurring around him.   Our food came out and it was consistently good on the way CPK is, which was great and appreciated. Overall, we were underwhelmed by the service of everyone except our bartender. I definitely won't be rushing back here.

This was our first time here. Food was beyond amazing and everything tasted fresh.  The kids had pizza and said it was "very good" I had the pea and barley soup, half Cesar with avocado added and then the fried Mac n' Cheese which was surprisingly yummy.  Service was a bit slow but not the servers (I can't recall her name) fault. From what we could see, there was a bartender and two servers on the floor. Our server did as good a job as possible with the amount of tables she had.  Not sure staffing short was intended though as it was mid afternoon and we came right at the beginning of a "rush" our server was polite and best of all, did not hold us hostage with the check.  We felt bad for her even though she never once complained about how busy she was. She handled it like a pro and seemed to enjoy her job. I'm grateful to have given this place a shot. We will be back!

TLDR: serves more than pizza. Very filling.  Dining area has a lot of booths and feels almost like a buffet. Average noise level. I'm pretty impressed with the variety in their menu. There are a lot of Asian style foods along with the typical pizzas. There are apps, small plates, and entrees--not just pizza! I honestly had a hard time not ordering everything I saw.  Service: wait to be seated, order at the table, check brought to table, your table will be bused. Complimentary bread and oil dip: bread is crunchy on the outside and chewy inside. Just how I like it. Oil dip is not very salty but is lightly herby. Smashed Chicken Meatball Piadina: Chicken is very tender and I'm a fan of that crushed tomato--tastes very fresh! Salty and tangy flavors blend nicely. Since it comes with soup I recommend you get the half size at lunch hour--a full size is way too filling especially with the soup! Baked Potato Soup: delightfully chunky and melt in your mouth consistency. Has a slight tang to it and is not too salty. Be warned--it's super filling! Sparkling Cranberry Cooler: a bit on sour side but refreshing nonetheless. Not as "sparkling" as I though it would be--low carbonation.

Went back here yesterday for the first time in years, because I was nearby and I remember the BBQ chicken pizza being tasty.  It was OK, but verrry light on the cheese. My friend ordered the spaghetti bolognese, and thought it was pretty "blah".  I tasted it and agreed... at $15 for a small plate of pasta plus a ladle or two of sauce, it should have been amazing.  Very little flavor at all, and for a meat sauce, little discernable meat... more like crumbles with some kind filler or extender in them.  The total cost of the ingredients (the noodles are dirt cheap) had to have been under $2, maybe even under $1. There just wasn't any flavor, and so overpriced. Overall, expensive for what it is, and disappointing.
